fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Hi there! Welcome to my forest. You can read more about me here.

Academic posts:
Three perspectives on quivers

A quiver is just a directed graph with an attitude! While fully descriptive, this popular statement is hardly elucidating. It follows a beloved mathematical tradition of explaining concepts in the most obtuse way possible.

My goal today is to do exactly the opposite: I will introduce the simple concept of a quiver in obnoxious detail, from three different perspectives. Buckle up, and join me in discovering in how many ways we can understand a bunch of dots and arrows.
We start by the most pedestrian of approaches: quivers as directed graphs.
A quiver \vec {Q} = (V, E, s, t) consists of:

fr:ul.fr:li: a pair of functions s, t \colon E \rightarrow V named source and target maps.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Two sets, and two functions, that's it! Moreover, these carry very intuitive meanings. Consider the following example of a quiver.
This consists of vertices V = \{a, b\} and a single edge E = \{v\}. The source and target maps encode the information that v has a source s(v) = a and target t(v) = b.
Equivalently, we could define edges v \in E as ordered pairs (a, b) \in V \times V, with entries the source and target vertices, respectively.

The Jordan quiver has one vertex and one edge. In this case we have V = \{ a \}, \quad E = \{ v \}, \quad so there is a unique choice of source and target maps s, t \colon v \longmapsto a. If we are not bothered to label the vertices and edges, we can represent the Jordan quiver as in the diagram

At this point, the reader might be wondering why such a simple definition warrants analysis from more than one point of view. This will become clear once we work through the definition of a morphism of quivers.

Let \vec {Q}_1 = (V_1, E_1, s_1, t_1) and \vec {Q}_2 = (V_2, E_2, s_2, t_2) be quivers. A morphism of quivers f = (f_V, f_E) \colon \vec {Q}_1 \rightarrow \vec {Q}_2 consists of two functions:
a mapping of vertices f_V \colon V_1 \rightarrow V_2;
a mapping of edges f_E \colon E_1 \rightarrow E_2; such that the diagrams commutes
\usepackage {tikz} \usepackage {tikz-cd}
\begin {tikzcd} E_1 \arrow [d, "s_1"] \arrow [r, "f_E"] & E_2 \arrow [d, "s_2"] \\ V_1 \arrow [r, "f_V"] & V_2 \end {tikzcd}, \quad \begin {tikzcd} E_1 \arrow [d, "t_1"] \arrow [r, "f_E"] & E_2 \arrow [d, "t_2"] \\ V_1 \arrow [r, "f_V"] & V_2 \end {tikzcd}.
In words, vertices are mapped to vertices and edges to edges, in a way that respects the source and target maps
s_2 \circ f_E = f_V \circ s_1, \quad t_2 \circ f_E = f_V \circ t_1.
Hi, I'm Rui. I'm a mathematician with experience in physics and computational modeling looking for interesting problems to solve!
My research interests are on the mathematics of quantum field theory.
I'm currently on the job market! Check out my rsum or reach out at rmp@ruimp.com.
